awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Tissue Engineered Sustainable Leather
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will investigate the application of a novel tissue engineering approach to the fabrication of animal products, in particular leather. The approach relies on the automated deposition of conveniently prepared multicellular units into a three dimensional arrangement. Biological structure formation takes place post deposition of the discrete units through the mobilization of shape-forming, morphogenetic processes akin to those in embryonic development, such as tissue fusion and cell sorting. A distinguishing feature of the technology is that it is fully biological; it uses only cells and cell-secreted substances. It has successfully been used for applications in regenerative medicine. This project takes the technology beyond regenerative medicine to produce animal products in an environmentally sustainable, resource-conscious and ethically acceptable way without slaughtering animals. The end product of this proof of concept Phase I project will be an engineered leather sample of about 10 cm by 10 cm and 0.5-1 mm thickness. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project has far-reaching implications for the public and society broadly. It represents a fundamental innovation in agriculturally-related manufacturing. The approach is a safe, economical, environmentally conscious and ethically acceptable alternative to present industrial leather production practices. It does not require the slaughtering of animals or their unethical treatment, as it uses cells harvested via biopsy. It enables reduction in livestock raised specifically for leather or meat (leather being a byproduct) and consequently in demand for resources. As the technology eliminates a number of leather production steps (e.g. de-hairing, de-fleshing, splitting, curing, bating), it also eliminates many of the most toxic stages thereby reducing environmental pollution. Since it allows for better control of composition and shape, it enables dramatic reduction in waste. Production can be largely local with all phases under the same roof, leading to savings in transportation, fuel, etc. The commercial applications of the proposed technology are broad with leather being an initial product and with other materials to follow. Given the unprecedented control over every processing step, the final products can be optimized in an application-dependent way.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: University of Missouri Life Sciences Business Incubator, 1601 S. Providence Rd.

por.por_cntn:
The key objective of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I proposal was to perform proof of concept research for the engineering of cultured leather for consumer products using the latest developments in tissue engineering. Cultured leather here means leather produced in the laboratory.

The leather and the related meat industry are among the most resource intensive and polluting industries. Modern Meadow, the company behind this research, aims to produce leather without polluting the environment, with much lower input of land, water, energy and chemicals as present day industrial practices and, importantly, without the need to slaughter animals.

Modern Meadow’s approach to fabricate leather follows as closely as possible the natural process. During the grant period several leather fabrication methods have been investigated, including bioprinting, pioneered by some of the cofounders of the company. Each method starts with the harvesting of specialized live cells, typically through harmless biopsies (or using cells from commercial sources). Cells are grown to desired numbers and then assembled by the specific method into a structure, which eventually gives rise to the analogue of the raw hide (skin of the slaughtered animal). As the engineered hide is produced by the same cells (dermal fibroblasts) as its natural counterpart, it contains the same cell secreted materials as its natural counterpart, in particular collagen. Collagen is shaped into sheets and sheets coupled to arrive at the desired thickness. The engineered hide is tanned, died and shaped to be compatible with the intended product, such as a leather bracelet, a specific outcome of this SBIR research. The attached image shows a sampling of leather produced during the lifetime of the project. The tanning of the engineered hide is free of a number of polluting steps, such as de-hairing and de-flashing, unavoidable phases in industrial leather production. A further advantage of the described fabrication process is that leather is produced without waste, as the engineered hide can be sized according of the intended product.

By the end of this NSF founded project Modern Meadow’s leather, at the laboratory scale, was estimated to be about a factor of ten more expensive than industrial leather. With the scaling up of production to commercial level, as intended by the continued activity of the company, it is expected that Modern Meadow’s leather will become price competitive with industrial leather.  

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2013
Modified by: Karoly R Jakab

  • Samples of leather resulting from the project
